ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about the indic religions and their beliefs and practices and literature, and I also greatly developed my creative writing skills with the weekly assignments.
A lot about South Asian religions, a good amount about poetry, but very very little about South Asian art.
Experience writing and reading poetry, knowledge of early Hinduism, and some art history.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: too many readings that didn't always feel relevant to the writing assignments. the short poetry assignments were fun though.

I think the only area where it could have been improved for me would be to focus more on art. All of the readings we did were incredibly interesting, but I would have appreciated to learn a little more about the art and architecture associated with these traditions.

Strengths: writing poetry was fun; some of the readings were fun. Weaknesses: was not an art history class; we weren't taught how to write poetry/how to improve our poetry; weekly reading presentations weren't conducive to learning or discussion
There wasn't a great deal of art history, but I didn't mindthe course was very strong and engaging, and I learned a lot about both Hinduism and poetry.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professor needs to realize that when classes are taught entirely over zoom, sometimes technology failure happens. It is COMPLETELY UNACCEPTABLE to threaten to lower a student's participation score just because they are having computer issues and they can't always have their camera on, or if their wifi is spotty and their connection keeps dropping out during class discussion. The university administration needs to hold professors more accountable for treating their students humanely.
I think given that this was a zoom seminar, the practices geared towards the covid pandemic were the best they could have been.
The course was very engaging despite being virtual.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. This course was incredibly interesting and engaging and I developed immensely as a writer through this course.
Yes! This course was very interesting and easy to engage with, and also very good in terms of creative writing and freedom within assignments.

Probably not. I really wanted to like this class, but I was expecting to learn a lot about art history when instead we just talked about religion and poetry. If the syllabus is revised to include more art/object-based discussions, I would reconsider my answerbut, for now, unfortunately, no.
Yes, it was very interesting and covered topics rarely discussed in Western history.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was only a virtual seminar.
